displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. So fifty percent above increase above would be fourteen points. Twenty-eight plus fourteen, that’s forty-two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So and the PSA is measured every month. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you went on this trial – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - you have a two out of three chance of getting the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately to that lymph node. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or you can have a one out of three chance to get in the observation group first. If you go in the observation group you’re gonna get no additional therapy. You’ll be getting your PSA checked every other month.

Patient: Um. Doctor: So that’s what D___ and I will work on. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. So I’ll to go - Doctor: Well then let me; I think she’s out here but I know she will have been in touch with you, but I think she wanted me to clear you today to say hey, that she’s still a candidate because his blood tests have improved and acts with – PSA isn’t bad. Okay. Uh are there questions that you guys have? So we talked about diet; we talked about Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But right now they’re going to spend a little bit more time seeing if the trial makes sense for you – Patient: Right. Doctor: and go through that. Family Member: So tomorrow at ten o’clock even if he has, he’s going to see the urologist, should we send you or will you be in touch with them or how? Doctor: We’ve been getting the notes from whoever you see. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Oh okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

displayed_text: Family Member: Multi-grain, right, okay multi-grain. Okay, so that’s it. Now I know this is early and he’s feeling fine, but somebody brought it up and I want to ask you. When he starts radiation, chemotherapy is it possible to get the medical marijuana or how is that to happen? Patient: I never used my form, so we Family Member: And so we need to know in what form you know he should take Doctor: I hope he doesn’t need marijuana have an Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s only people who you know just have nausea that just can’t be controlled by medicines - Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then we would use marijuana. Family Member: Okay, that’s what I was told - Family Member: Just to stop vomiting and that so she mentioned that her son um had cancer. And so she mentioned that and I said I will ask. Doctor: So any other questions? Family Member: No.

Family Member: Your urine. Patient: Yeah. Okay. No problem. Doctor: But you’re not leaking or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: How many times you up at night to pee? Patient: Hum, once or twice at night. Doctor: Okay. Have you been to the hospital since I saw you? Patient: No. Doctor: So you feel like you’re holding your own, getting worse, feeling better? Patient: Yeah, hum, I’m holding my own. Doctor: Any falls? Patient: No.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m not exactly sure when that will happen. But it accelerates and that happens sooner. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace you know if it increases by one or two decimal points, who knows, it may take you know six to nine months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Maybe up to twelve months. So one of the things that I wanted to discuss with both of you today is what we would do if it reached one. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay so the first thing would be to check and see uh if the cancer is still visible or invisible. In other words can we see the cancer on scan – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - whether bone scan or CAT scan? Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Or is it still invisible and can we not see it? Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Can’t be sure? Doctor: Well, let me explore, so I’ve got a couple of threads I’ve got to explore a little more. Patient: Thank you. I appreciate that. Doctor: So let’s uh- Patient: So we’re off the trial now? Doctor: Yeah. We’re off the trial. We’ll probably just want to see a PSA in another month off the testosterone. That may be complicated because you may, because we’re working to go somewhere else so, it may not be that useful for us because it’s not like you’re going to be on- Healthcare Professional: Is it thirty days as before? In those terms I don’t know- Doctor: We’ll, we’ll see. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Perfect. Doctor: And so I will be in touch by the end of the week to tell you what I’ve, what I’ve learned. Okay? Patient: Alright. Thank you. Doctor: So just for, for now, Germany, I get what they want, the test results, uh, I’ll see what the policy says about you know just paying for, for the drugs. Okay? Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Three months. So at what point does the prostate shrink? Doctor: That’s our hope. Family Member: OHH! Patient: So should I be wearing this catheter for a while then? Doctor: Well because again it could be as early as this week that they feel like you can pee on your own. But if that’s what they’re going to be testing - Patient: And they cannot test it any other way except by pulling it out. Doctor: Right. Patient: Putting it in. Two times they put it in. And both times I was in E.R., and there were some nurses that were putting it in, they said they were experienced by they were not. They couldn’t do it properly. It was going the wrong way. And then uh the first time over the overnight, and the next day another nurse came from urology department. And she was able to do it. The second time when I went for only one night, again two local nurses you know tried to put it in, they couldn’t do it. They did it wrong. And then they called the urologist that was on duty and she came. She was a Doctor: I’m with ya. Okay, so how’s your appetite? Patient: It’s fine . My wife changed the diet completely; now I’ve been Family Member: And I was bringing him food but didn’t eat that food, it was horrible. And now his appetite is really good. Doctor: And your bowels are moving daily?

Family Member: Right, the part two – part one of this phase one series. Doctor: Oh I see okay got it. So it’s the dose expansion. Yeah so far there are some people who have benefited and been on it for quite a while. So there is some preliminary evidence of his Family Member: Just not a lot of data. Doctor: Yeah but it’s not – the numbers are not that big to really say statistics. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I would say probably two or three people out of the ten, but some of them haven’t even had their first scan yet. So it’s a work in progress. Family Member: Sure. Uh is there any data on uh chemotherapy? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Chemotherapy is standard and approved. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the chances of that helping the – the other part is a lot of these new treatments like the Xofigo for instance, the radiation, it doesn’t make the PSA go down. So its the PSA effect is frequently treatment dependent. Okay so chemotherapy or XTANDI for that matter we know it makes the PSA go down if it’s working. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But not so for Xofigo and for this new medication honestly we don’t know enough- Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Oh, my God! Wow Doctor: But I didn’t know it was my patient because rightly so they didn’t allow him to call from his cellphone. Patient: That makes sense. Doctor: So they had to call from the border. Oh, man! So then I was like oh, my gosh, then I was like well, how do I know you are who you say you are so I gave it right back to him and I go so, you know, what’s your phone number so just to be safe I called the guy back. I was like I don’t know who this person is, you know, it might be… Patient: Right, that’s a good point. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah and then, you know, there he was. Patient: Wow, wow. Doctor: So, then the next day when, you know, it was Monday afternoon my patient called and he goes okay, we’re never gonna do that again. I’m like, because he got his dose like Friday Patient: Right. Doctor: and then he traveled Sunday and I was like okay, that will teach you not to do that. So, now, I reported that back so now every single time, and they didn’t give him the card because they’re like it’s so low you won’t Patient: You won’t know yeah. Doctor: set off anything, you’ll be fine. After that incident, everybody gets a card. That’s a longwinded way of saying, everybody gets a card.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The PSA tells me it’s either this time or three months from now that we’re likely to see a change. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But that’s what we’ve learned about Enzalutamide; don’t give up the ship until it’s clearly different. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because these drugs could be providing a dampening effect Patient: Yeah, I know that. Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: So. Um. You know, my sense is that it is research because we’ve got a new drug added to it. You know, looking forward to having the conversation about what options might be still important. Um. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um. Um. (Pause5sec) Patient: So, why don’t we try to, to, to have the blood taken and, and, see if, if what that brings back, but maybe a a - in lieu of that possibly being negative, um, look at the other clinical trial. Doctor: So, I’ll go print out, uh, do you want me to just not print out the chemo one?

Healthcare Professional: - and as long as he’s not progressing on the pills - Doctor: Right. Healthcare Professional: - we’ll continue to give them. Family Member: Now is there any way that say at one o’clock in the morning - Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: - he starting vomiting, he started getting dizzy - Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: - and weak, is there someone I can call? Doctor: Yeah me. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You would page me and if it’s not me it’s the doctor covering me um and if it’s you can’t get anybody, you call uh if it’s severe you call the ambulance, you call nine one one. Family Member: Nine one one yeah right, right, right. Okay. Doctor: Yeah um hmm.

Patient: Then I got a, then I got Doctor: Then, you got to try it. I don’t see you using it. Patient: I got it down ‘cuz it don’t, it don’t really be working for me. You know what I’m sayin’? ‘Cuz all I do is when I stop, I lean on it, lean down on it. I’d settle for the one with the seat on it. Now see, that’s the one that, um, I gotta see, if, if you can, can you see when the next time I can get one? The one with the seat on it? Doctor: The walker with the seat? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’ll give you script for that to take… Patient: Now see, I have, I have to, I have to always sit, I have to always sit down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know, because I be fatigued. Doctor: I see. Not a problem. Patient: You know what I’m saying? And, that, that’s the only problem (XXX) Doctor: I’ll give you a script take it over to Vincent’s or whatever and see what they say.

Patient: Are you smoking? Come on. Family Member: Whoa wait a minute. Patient: There’s a disconnect you change your… Family Member: Did you see my face? Patient: Probably mine too but uh – but who did we hear routine would be six? Who told us six? Family Member: I don’t know… Patient: Was that Dr. Y or W? Family Member: I don’t know. Wayne maybe. I don’t know. Patient: Somebody made a comment that… Doctor: I think you know so all the studies, they try to go up to ten. They try to go up to ten. So we just try to chunk – you’re a little off cycle because you know we started off with the vitamin C thing so three more and then… Family Member: Seriously, we need three more? Doctor: Yeah. We want ten total.

Patient: About this? Doctor: About this and also about the Xtandi itself. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because the the Xtandi will be a part of the treatment anyways. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um so I’m I’m going to go ahead and try to get that one authorized in the meantime. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once once you decide, if you decide to participate in the clinical trial, then you will come back and there will be a screening visit. Or uh we’re going to go through all the eligibility with you. Do a physical exam, go through a CT scan and a bone scan. It’s a little bit more involved. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um if you decide the trial doesn’t sound right for you, then I am going to start the standard Xtandi and we’re going to send it up, send the medication to you house hopefully after its reimbursed. Patient: Right. Patient: No. Uh uh. Oh, you all gon’ call me today or tomorrow about the blood work, right?

Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No.
